recommendations: Pique Turn is a movement performed in the passé position while turning to the inside and  usually done in a series.. For practicing Pique Turn as a/an advanced performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Plie variations: To warm up your legs and improve your turnout, try doing grand plies in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as demi-plies with various arm positions., Releve variations: Work on strengthening your calves and ankles with releve exercises. Try doing single-leg and double-leg releves in first, second, and fifth positions, as well as releve passe exercises to help prepare for the pique turn., Arabesque balances: Work on improving your balance and control by practicing arabesque balances. Start with a low arabesque and gradually work your way up to a higher arabesque position., Spotting exercises: Practicing spotting exercises can help improve your balance and control during the pique turn. Try doing half-turns or full turns with a focus on spotting, and gradually increase the speed and difficulty of the turns., Flexibility stretching: Stretch out your muscles before practicing pique turns to help prevent injury and improve your flexibility. Focus on stretching your legs, hips, and back, and incorporate stretches for your shoulders and arms as well. for 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Start with your feet in first position, with your heels touching and your toes turned out. Make sure your weight is evenly distributed between both feet and your core muscles are engaged to help with balance and control., Prepare for the turn by lifting your back foot into a pique position, bringing it to the back of your supporting ankle. Hold this position firmly and securely, and make sure your weight is centered over your supporting foot., Use your supporting leg to initiate the turn by pushing off the ground and lifting your pique foot into a passe position in front of your knee. Keep your core muscles engaged and your arms in a comfortable position for balance and control., As you turn, pivot on your supporting leg and bring your pique foot around to the front, pointing your toes and keeping your leg straight. Keep your eyes focused on a fixed point in front of you to help with spotting, and use your core muscles to help you maintain your balance and control throughout the turn., Complete the turn by landing on your supporting leg with your pique foot still in front of your knee. To challenge yourself, try doing multiple turns in a row and experiment with different arm positions. for 5 repetitions on each side for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras: Work on your port de bras by practicing flowing arm movements, focusing on making smooth transitions and expressive gestures., Dance to different music: Explore different styles of music and try dancing to each one, focusing on expressing the mood and emotion of the music through your movements., Free movement improvisation: Let your body move freely and spontaneously, without any set choreography. Focus on expressing yourself through movement and exploring different levels and dynamics..

Jazz Contraction is a contraction of the muscles in the back of the legs, which is used to create a higher jump.. For practicing Jazz Contraction as a/an intermediate performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Pilates roll-up, Yoga boat pose, Seated twists for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart., Bend knees, lowering into plié., Curve spine forward, contracting core., Drop head, maintaining neck alignment., Add fluid arm movements for style. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras, Dance to different music, Free movement improvisation.

Fish Roll and Flop is a movement where the dancer rolls their body in a fluid motion resembling the movement of a fish, while the Flop is a contemporary dance move where the dancer falls to the ground in a sudden and dramatic manner.. For practicing Fish Roll and Flop as a/an amateur performance, the recommended warm-up exercises are Shoulder shrugs: Stand with your arms at your sides and your shoulders relaxed. Shrug your shoulders up towards your ears, hold for a few seconds, then release and lower them back down., Arm circles: Stand with your arms extended out to the sides, parallel to the ground. Begin making circular motions with your arms, first small and gradually increasing the size of the circles. Repeat in the opposite direction., Cat-cow stretch: Begin on your hands and knees, with your wrists under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Arch your back and tuck your chin towards your chest, then release and let your belly drop towards the ground, lifting your head and tailbone towards the ceiling. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. After warming up, you should practice the following instructions: Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart., Lift your right shoulder up and back, simultaneously lifting your left shoulder up and forward., Move your right shoulder down and forward, then move your left shoulder down and back, alternating continuously., Focus on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement., Practice regularly to improve your technique and coordination. for 5 repetitions for 10 minutes. Since you want to particularly focus on artistry, additional exercises could include Flowing port de bras, Dance to different music, Free movement improvisation.
